content.description:
Start on the large, semi-detached flake that reaches the ground about 15' to the right of You're a Trad Dad Now.  Climb up the generous, left-angling features over blocky holds and nice crimps until you pull onto a ledge.  Stay to the right over blocky holds, pull over the edge of the domed slab feature at the top of the route and follow a great, left-angled finger crack on positive terrain to the top.

Deceptively gentle - you'll be well into injury territory before you can get your first placement into a horizontal crack right before you pull the crux moves onto the slab.



About 15' to the right of You're a Trad Dad Now.

Small-medium cam in high, horizontal crack, followed by smaller cams in top out crack.

Climb the obvious crack that splits two successive bulges on the climber's left side of the cliff.  It's been bolted, but easily leads on trad with smaller pro.



Very obvious crack on obvious bulge.

Four bolts to rap anchors

Climb the prow to the right of the bulge with the crack next to the detached boulders.



To climber's right of the cracked bulge.  Top rope anchors are on a higher ledge to the right of those for the crack.

Top rope anchors only

Climb face to the right of the prow through ledges and crimps.  Shares the top rope anchor with Unknown 4.



Face to the right of the prow of Unknown 2.

Top rope anchors only

Use the same top rope anchors as Unknown 3, but climb the incredibly chossy part of the face to climber's right.  Why?  "Because it's there".



Immediately to the right of Unknown 3.  

Top rope anchors only.

On the wall immediately to climber's right of the unknown, chossy topropes, find the large, obvious flake about 10' above the ground.  A few burly, bouldery moves gain a deep undercling at the bottom of the flake.  Go right through a flake so positive it basically shouts "you got this, bro" as you move through it to a ledge.  Finish up and to the right with the big, blocky crack.

Crash pad recommended for the opening - bad, downhill fall if you fail.  Also, don't put a cam into the flake until you're past the underclinging section because the undercling is thin and has some choss and a cam might break it.



Around 20' to climber's right of the unknown, chossy topropes.

Smaller to medium cams at the bottom, large cams for the top.

The area is defined by a noticeable granite face at the very end of the Ravine on the waterfront on the opposite side of the Ravine as the Main Cliff.

The names of the original lead and toprope routes have been lost.  However, new routes in the area are going in and there remains some development potential.  

The bouldering in the area is immediately to climber's right of the main wall and consists of a multi-tiered series of walls that cascades down from the top of the cliff to the waterfront, forming a pleasant series of hanging boreal gardens (be gentle to the flora where you can).  Most of each tier has a good ledge to begin climbing from and offers reasonable landings.  Each route is topped out by reaching the ledge at the bottom of the next tier.

There is additional bouldering potential in this general area.
